title: How to get on a college professor's good side - Quora

response.answer_text: TL;DR: Ask good questions. Assuming you’re just in a professor’s class, then it’s pretty easy to get on a professor’s good side. Professors work pretty hard and have lots of responsibilities that go far beyond the class room. Most professors generally enjoy teaching, but most univerisities say that a course should typically account for 25% of their effort per class. So they’re supposed to be putting in 10 or so hours per week. This time should include the class time, the prep for each class, the creation of the homework and exams, the grading of the exams, and the office hours. If that sounds like a tall order, it is and most professors generally they go far beyond that allotted time. With that in mind, most professors want to feel like they are making a difference in the education of the students. Most professors don’t consider grades part of the education, so asking about every point on a homework or exam is not going get on their good side. Student work is meant to help students diagnose their own understanding and help them with the learn the material, it is not the end-all. Asking well-formed questions about in-course material that you find confusing is really valuable. Chances are other students have similar confusions and so these types of good questions can help the entire class. Good questions are all unique, but bad questions come in lots of common shapes and sizes. When students are trying to ask good questions, they typically run afoul in common ways asking about something out of context to the classIn Calc 2, asking “How does this relate to Stokes theorem?” — to which the professor thinks “umm it does, but only one or two people in the class have the context to understand it.”asking about something that is nit-picky“Is that 2.5 centimeters per inch or 2.54?” — to which the professor thinks “were you really confused about that?”(I’ll try to expand this later). Good questions are ones that are about synthesizing information. Oftentimes there are long discussions on something specific and the main point can get lost. If the professor doesn’t circle back to the big picture, asking “What is the bigger picture of X?”“I don’t see how X and Y relate?”if it was about an example “How is X an example of Y?”“How is X used in practice?”These will likely stimulate good discussion and they’re about learning the material.

Demonstrate genuine interest in the subject matter by reading ahead, thinking, and asking good questions. Do the very best work you can, and seek help when you are stuck. Put in the work. Then do some more … master the assigned material, and then think beyond that, to further implications and connections with what you have learned. Make connections to other subjects you are interested in, especially if there is something you might know more about than the prof, because profs love to learn from their students. Think rigorously, not sloppily. If your course material requires writing, draft and rewrite and polish until it is the best you can do, and then study your prof’s critique of your writing so that you can do it even better next time. If your course involves projects, draft and revise and polish your projects until they are the best you can do, and then study the feedback you receive so that you can do it even better next time. Go to office hours, but go prepared: Make good use of your prof’s time by getting as far as you can before asking questions, whether they are questions about the assigned work or questions on related material of interest to you. Be humble, but be courageous enough to share ideas you are not sure of. It isn’t easy. You can’t fake it. But if you have a genuine interest in the prof’s subject, and are willing to work for it, that’s what it takes.
